entry.dc:subject: Visit Mudcat
entry.content:
Our studio is located just two blocks from where the riverboats dock on the Ohio River. The 160-year-old three-story commercial building has been a coffeehouse, a hotel, tenements and a feed store. We look forward to continuing its interesting history.

Darlene's studio is open most days 1 to 5 p.m. Will open for appointments as well.

Location: The Mudcat studio is located at 301 Jefferson St. in historic downtown Madison, Indiana (the most beautiful rivertown in America if you haven't heard).

You'll find easy parking right across the street!
[ Get a map ]

Occasionally business pulls us out of town. If you're planning on stopping in town feel free to call or email ahead to double-check we'll be open. (812) 265-2445 or darlene@mudcatpottery.com

entry.dc:subject: About Mudcat
entry.content: "Using nature as a springboard for ideas, I create one of a kind sculptural vessels and wheel thrown pottery," Darlene says. "I am greatly interested in texture and the natural properties of clay. I use a combination of original earthy and bright glazes in gently overlapping patterns to accentuate the forms."

entry.dc:subject: Services
entry.content: The trick to shipping pots in the mail is to double box them. Wrap the pot in bubble wrap and place in a box slightly larger than the wrapped pot. Fill in the dead spaces with styrofoam peanuts. Then suspend this box in a larger box with a couple inches width of peanuts on all four sides of the box. We ship U.S. Mail as UPS charges a lot more for oversized boxes.

entry.dc:subject: How it's made
entry.content:
Obviously, the idea comes first. Our Madison tile came from a series of photos taken by Darlene of downtown Madison from atop the Kentucky bluffs.

Darlene first sketched the the scene on the slab of clay. Slowly clay is added and carved away to provide detail and volume to the tile. At right, Darlene uses a clay tool to pull aside clay from the dome of the Jefferson County Courthouse.

Darlene worked on this tile when it was too hot to do anything else in the summer of 2004. It took two days to finish.

Once the original tile is finished and dried, plaster is poured around the master to create a mold. In turn, once the mold is dry, we press clay into the mold to create the individual tiles.

The tiles are then fired twice, once to 1800F to bake out the impurities in the clay and a second time for the glaze to 2200F.
